FLea: Improving federated learning on scarce and label-skewed data via privacy-preserving feature augmentation

Tong Xia
University of Cambridge
&Abhirup Ghosh
University of Birmingham
&Cecilia Mascolo
University of Cambridge
Abstract

Learning a global model by abstracting the knowledge, distributed across multiple clients, without aggregating the raw data is the primary goal of Federated Learning (FL). Typically, this works in rounds alternating between parallel local training at several clients, followed by model aggregation at a server. We found that existing FL methods under-perform when local datasets are small and present severe label skew as these lead to over-fitting and local model bias. This is a realistic setting in many real-world applications. To address the problem, we propose FLea, a unified framework that tackles over-fitting and local bias by encouraging clients to exchange privacy-protected features to aid local training. The features refer to activations from an intermediate layer of the model, which are obfuscated before being shared with other clients to protect sensitive information in the data. FLea leverages a novel way of combining local and shared features as augmentations to enhance local model learning. Our extensive experiments demonstrate that FLea outperforms the start-of-the-art FL methods, sharing only model parameters, by up to 17.6%percent17.617.6\%, and FL methods that share data augmentations by up to 6.3%percent6.36.3\%, while reducing the privacy vulnerability associated with shared data augmentations.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) extracts knowledge from segregated data silos into a global model, avoiding the need to centralize the data in a single repository. The learning process is achieved through iterations between local model training and global model aggregation. Such inherent characteristics of decentralized training make FL highly suitable for privacy-sensitive applications like healthcare and financeÂ (Rieke etÂ al., 2020; Li etÂ al., 2020a; Nguyen etÂ al., 2021).

The most widely used aggregation strategy in FL is average aggregationÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), where the local model parameters are averaged based on weights proportional to the size of the local data. Typically, lower aggregation weights are assigned to local models trained on smaller datasets, indicating their relatively weaker performance and lesser contribution to the global model. Nevertheless, one problem arising from such an approach is the inability to handle data scarcity, which refers to the situation where all clients have a limited number of samples. When all clients possess small-sized datasets, aggregating the models trained on such scarce data could become unreliable: In Sec.Â 3.2, we show that in the presence of data scarcity, local models are more susceptible to over-fitting, i.e., they fit training samples very well but struggle to generalize to unseen testing data even if from the same distribution. In such cases, aggregating these models does not improve the global modelâ€™s generalization ability. This, in turn, slows down convergence and negatively impacts the performance of the global model.

The problem could become even more pronounced when the local label distribution varies, a phenomenon referred to as label skew. This is a common scenario in real-world FL applicationsÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Zhu etÂ al., 2021). Label skew alone can lead to model bias: local models are over-fitted by the local distribution and struggle to generalize to the global distribution. This is known as client drift, which consequently leads to a sub-optimal global modelÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Luo etÂ al., 2021). When local datasets are both small and label-skewed, local models are likely to fail to generalize to both in-local and out-of-local distributions. Aggregating these models does not help. It is prevalent for data scarcity and label skew to occur concurrently in the real world, such as when clients are edge devices collecting data only about a small group of individualsÂ (Nguyen etÂ al., 2022) or within a limited geographical locationÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2021). While numerous studies aim to address the label skew problem in FL, the feasibility of those methods when dealing with skewed and scarce data simultaneously is still under-explored.

We categorize those FL methods into two groups: loss-based and data augmentation-based methods. The first set of methods aims to regularize the local models by modifying the local training loss to mitigate biasÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b; Shi etÂ al., 2022; Zhang etÂ al., 2022a; Lee etÂ al., 2022). However, these methods face significant challenges when dealing with limited local data since they require a balance between local optimization and global knowledge preservation. In Sec.Â 3.1, we demonstrate that the state-of-the-art loss-based methods under-perform as data scarcity increases. The second category of those methods proposes exchanging a global data proxy, such as a portion of raw data, aggregated data, or synthetic data, along with sharing model parametersÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Yoon etÂ al., 2020; Liu etÂ al., 2022). Although these methods tend to outperform the loss-based approaches in the presence of data scarcity, performance improvement often comes at the cost of added privacy vulnerabilities. For example, FedMixÂ (Yoon etÂ al., 2020) shares average (over mini-batches) data samples, which may reveal sensitive information consistently embedded in the entire batch of data (as illustrated in Sec.Â 3.3). As summarized in TableÂ 1, our work, for the first time in the literature, addresses the challenges posed by data scarcity and label skew simultaneously, while preserving data privacy.

We propose FLea, a novel framework where clients exchange features along with the model parameters. Features here refer to activations from an intermediate layer of the model, given the input data. This main idea is that in deep neural networks, features not only are meaningful for classification but also provide an opportunity to protect the privacy associated with raw dataÂ (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2020). In practical terms, FLea utilizes a global feature buffer that gathers feature-label pairs from multiple clients as a global proxy to aid local training. A novel feature augmentation approach is proposed to combine local and global features to alleviate both local over-fitting and model bias. A knowledge distillation strategy is also applied to the combined features in order to further prevent local model bias. To protect data privacy, features are shared by clients after applying some level of â€œobfuscationâ€: we reduce the correlation between the features and the data, while maintaining their classification characters via a customized loss function. Although data augmentation has been explored in FLÂ (Yoon etÂ al., 2020; Guo etÂ al., 2023), to the best of our knowledge, we are the first to design feature-level augmentation for FL, which enhances data privacy protection.

Our main contributions are:

  • â€¢

    The first study on a common but under-explored scenario in FL, where all the clients possess limited and highly label-skewed data. We find that model over-fitting caused by data scarcity is under-looked by existing methods.

  • â€¢

    A novel framework FLea to enable privacy-protected feature sharing in FL system. FLea, proposes an augmentation-based strategy to address both data scarcity and label skew.

  • â€¢

    Extensive experiments with different levels of label skew and data scarcity show that FLea consistently outperforms baselines with only requiring clients to exchange a small proportion of the features. We also empirically demonstrate that the data privacy can be preserved from the shared features.

2 Preliminaries and Related Works

2.1 Federated Learning and FedAvg

Formally, a FL system learns a global model from a set of collaborating clients, Kğ¾K, with each client kğ‘˜k containing a local dataset ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}. A typical FL system works in synchronous rounds. At the start of each round tğ‘¡t, the FL server broadcasts the current global model parameters Î¸(tâˆ’1)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta^{(t-1)} to the randomly selected subset of the clients ğ’¦(t)âŠ†Ksuperscriptğ’¦ğ‘¡ğ¾\mathcal{K}^{(t)}\subseteq K. Each client kâˆˆğ’¦(t)ğ‘˜superscriptğ’¦ğ‘¡k\in\mathcal{K}^{(t)} take a few optimization steps (e.g., using stochastic gradient descend) starting from Î¸(tâˆ’1)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta^{(t-1)}, resulting in an updated local model Î¸k(t)subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜\theta^{(t)}_{k}. The local optimization aims to minimize the loss function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} on local data ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}, i.e., Î¸k=argâ€‹minÎ¸â¡â„’â€‹(Î¸,ğ’Ÿk|Î¸(tâˆ’1))subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptargminğœƒâ„’ğœƒconditionalsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜superscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta_{k}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta,\mathcal{D}_{k}|\theta^{(t-1)}). Each round tğ‘¡t ends with model aggregation to derive the new global model Î¸(t)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta^{(t)}. The most basic and popular aggregation method, FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) averages the model parameters weighted by the fraction of local data size in the clients,

2.2 Label skew in FL

The above FedAvg has been shown to converge to the optimal model with local data ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} sampled from the same distributionÂ (Li etÂ al., 2019), also popularly known as the IID (independent and identically distributed) setting. However, when ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} are sampled from diverse distributions, known as non-IID setting, FedAvg usually produces low-performing models. Label skew is a typical non-IID FL problem for classificationÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Zhu etÂ al., 2021; Guo etÂ al., 2023).

To mitigate the client drift, methods were proposed to improve loss function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}. For classification, â„’â„’\mathcal{L} typically represents the cross-entropy loss between the target class and the prediction, termed as â„’câ€‹lâ€‹fsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘“\mathcal{L}_{clf}. To compensate for missing categories in the local data, an additional regularization FedDecorrÂ (Shi etÂ al., 2022) discovered that severe data heterogeneity leads to dimensional collapse in FL models, prompting the introduction of regularization techniques to address this issue, â„’rsubscriptâ„’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{L}_{r}, can be included. FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b) regulates the discrepancy between the local and global model parameters. FedNTDÂ (Lee etÂ al., 2022) penalizes changes in the logit distribution predicted by global and local models. This penalty is applied to classes excluding the ground truth class for each sample, striking a balance between local learning and global knowledge preservation. MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) leverages constructive learning to maximize the distance between low-dimensional features and other classes, thereby improving feature learning. In addition to those methods proposing a new term â„’rsubscriptâ„’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{L}_{r}, FedLCÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022a) directly re-scales the logits to derive a calibrated â„’câ€‹lâ€‹fsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘“\mathcal{L}_{clf}. This calibration effectively mitigates classifier bias, leading to enhancements in the final global model.

Being orthogonal to a bias-agnostic loss function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}, data augmentations were also developed. Zhao et al. proposed to share a small proportion of local data globally, alongside the model parameters, to enhance FedAvgÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018). For example, globally sharing 5%percent55\% of the data yielded an improvement of up to 20%percent2020\%. For ease of presentation, we named this method FedData throughout the paper. Despite the desirable performance gains brought by FedData, collecting private data would compromise the privacy-preservation benefits of FL. Other global proxies that are less privacy-sensitive than raw data have been explored as alternatives. FedMixÂ (Yoon etÂ al., 2020) and FedBRÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023) average data over mini-batches and share this aggregated data globally, while CCVRÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2021) shares low-dimensional features with the server to calibrate the global model on the server side. These low-dimensional features are also known as class prototypes, which are explored to mitigate local classifier biasÂ (Tan etÂ al., 2022b). FedGenÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2022) and VHLÂ (Tang etÂ al., 2022) generate some random but separable data samples to aid local learning. Although no raw information is shared by those two approaches, their performance highly depends on the quantity and quality of synthetic data, usually yielding marginal gains over FedAvg.

The above-mentioned methods are developed to prevent the global model from diverging under label skew, while another way to cope with this issue is to learn a personalized model per client, with the goal of enhancing performance within their local data distributionÂ (Kulkarni etÂ al., 2020; Tan etÂ al., 2022a; Kotelevskii etÂ al., 2022). Recently, personalized FL methods based on variational Bayesian inference have shown promising results, supported by theoretical guaranteesÂ (TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2022b; Zhu etÂ al., 2023). However, these methods still face challenges in learning an optimal global model.

2.3 Data scarcity in FL

Data scarcity is a common yet under-explored challenge in FL. As first observed byÂ (Li etÂ al., 2022) (c.f. Finding 7), the accuracy of FedAvg and FedProx decreases as the number of clients increases (reducing local data size). Despite the proliferation of FL methods, including the methods mentioned earlier, most of them are evaluated on large local datsets, each possessing thousands of samples. This leaves their effectiveness in handling data scarcity unclear. Although experimental studies target on scarce settingÂ (Charles etÂ al., 2021; Zhu etÂ al., 2023), they failed to justify if the performance gain is from alleviating the bias or the overfitting caused by data scarify, thus lack in providing a deep understanding. FedScale introduced the first benchmark featuring thousands of clients with limited training dataÂ (Lai etÂ al., 2022). However, FedScale primarily focuses on system efficiency and offers limited insight into algorithm effectiveness. Some client selection methods, such as discarding or reducing aggregation weights for clients with limited dataÂ (Nishio & Yonetani, 2019; AbdulRahman etÂ al., 2020), improve overall performance while reducing communication overheads. However, these methods may not be effective when all clients face data scarcity issues.

2.4 Privacy-preserving FL

Although FL aims to protect privacy via gathering model parameters instead of data, studies discovered that privacy can still be leaked from the parameters when malicious attacks existÂ (Dang etÂ al., 2021; Wei etÂ al., 2020). To enhance security, homomorphic encryption, secure aggregation, differential privacy and other techniques have been developed to defend from malicious attacksÂ (Yin etÂ al., 2021). These works are orthogonal to our method and can be applied in our framework. We focus on data privacy regarding the shared features. The most related works are protecting the privacy for the shared activations in splitting learning, where the server gathers activations to train part of the modelÂ (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2020; He etÂ al., 2020). Different from those studies, we explore FL where model training merely happens on the client side.

3 Limitation of previous work and Insights

In this section, we reveal the limitations of previous work when applied to FL with scarce label-skewed data, and provide insights to address those limitations.

3.1 Empirical comparison of previous work

We use CIFAR10 and compare the global modelâ€™s accuracy on the global testing set. FedAvg is compared with the best loss-based methods FedDecorr and FedNTD, and the best data augmentation-based methods FedMix and FedData. To simulate varying label skew and scarcity levels, we split the CIFAR10 training set into 500050005000, 500500500, and 100100100 samples per client containing all ten classes (IID setting) or randomly chosen three classes (non-IID setting) (we refer the local data size as |ğ’Ÿk|subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜|\mathcal{D}_{k}|). More experimental details are presented in AppendixÂ A.

The results are summarized in FigureÂ 1. We draw the following conclusions: 1) FedAvg degrades remarkably as data scarcity and label skew increase. Its accuracy of 757575% in (a) with sufficient IID data decreases to 565656% in (c) when |ğ’Ÿk|subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜|\mathcal{D}_{k}| reduces to 100, and drops to 60%percent6060\% in (d) when the data becomes non-IID. Other methods present similar degrading trend. 2) The compared loss-based methods can address label skew only with sufficient local data. In (d), FedDecorr improves FedAvg by 10%percent1010\% and performs closely to FedData. Yet, in (e) and (f), the advantage of FedDecorr disappears. While FedNTD consistently outperforms FedAvg, its accuracy still lags significantly behind FedData. 3) The compared data augmentation-based methods perform well at the cost of privacy leakage. With the internal data exchange, FedMix and FedData mitigate the bias and improve local generalization simultaneously, leading to remarkable performance gains over FedAvg. When the data scarcity is significant (|ğ’Ÿk|=100subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜100|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=100), they notably outperform loss-based FL methods. However, it is worth considering that FedMix and FedData induce more privacy vulnerabilities compared to loss-based method due to sharing more data related information.

3.2 Effect of data scarcity

To gain a deeper understanding on the impact of data scarcity, we conduct analysis in the IID setting. We empirically demonstrate that data scarcity can lead to local model over-fitting, and aggregating such models will result in the degradation of the global model.

Following a previous study that visualizes the model bias caused by label skew using the features from the penultimate layerÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023), we leverage those low-dimensional features to understand model over-fitting. We look at one communication round where local training start from a global model with an accuracy of 40%percent4040\%. The training results are compared using different amount of local data, i.e., |ğ’Ÿk=5000||\mathcal{D}_{k}=5000| and |ğ’Ÿk=100||\mathcal{D}_{k}=100|. We employ the clustering score (Davies-Bouldin Score (DB)) to measure the separation of the features among classes (a detailed formulation can be found in AppendixÂ A). As illustrated in FigureÂ 2 (left), a smaller DB indicates less overlapped features. The DBs before and after local training are summarized in the bar chart of FigureÂ 2. It can be observed that the gap of DB in the training set and testing set is consistently present, however the fewer the samples (|ğ’Ÿk|=100subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜100|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=100), the bigger the gap, suggesting that the over-fitting is server. Based on local models: although features for local training set are distinguishable (small DB), the features for the testing set are not (big DB). Consequently, after aggregation, the performance of the global model varies, and training with 100100100 samples cannot enhance the global model (an increased DB). Those results uncover that data scarcity could impact the generalization of local models, yielding overlapped features, and finally leads to under-performed global model.

As shown in the fourth group (|ğ’Ÿk|=100+1000subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜1001000|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=100+1000), with more shared data to aid local training, the local modelâ€™s generalization is improved from the third group (a smaller gap between training and testing set), and thus the global modelâ€™s performance is improved (a decreased DB). This also explains why data augmentation-based methods are feasible for data scarcity in FL.

3.3 Privacy vulnerability mitigation via feature sharing

Data augmentation-based methods may increase privacy vulnerability. As shown in FigureÂ 8, raw data and labels are shared globally in FedData while aggregated data and labels are shared globally in FedMix. Although the average of samples in FedMix hinders the data reconstruction, it is still privacy vulnerable, as this will release context information. Considering an application where the clientâ€™s phone has a camera sensor problem so that each photo has a spot (see FigureÂ 8(a*))), or the client lives in a busy neighborhood and thus all audio clips have a constant background score. Averaging over a batch of samples will not protect such context information, as shown in FigureÂ 8(b*).

To improve the trade-offs between performance and privacy protection, we propose to share features from the intermediary layers (see FigureÂ 8(c*))). We try to mitigate privacy vulnerability from three aspects: i) reducing the feature exposure when sharing, ii) hindering the data reconstruction from the features, and iii) increasing the difficulty of the above-mentioned context identification.

4 FLea

FLea corrects the bias introduced by label skew and alleviates the over-fitting caused by data scarcity by using the shared features to aid local training. In FLea, the server will maintain a global model and a feature buffer which contains feature-target pairs from multiple clients. In the beginning, the global model is randomly initialized and the buffer is empty. Then FLea works in a iterative manner to updates the global model and the buffer. As illustrated in FigureÂ 4, each round of FLea starts with synchronizing the global model parameters Î¸(t)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta^{(t)} and feature buffer â„±(t)superscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{(t)} to the selected clients ğ’¦(t)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘¡\mathcal{K}^{(t)}. Once local training using ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} and â„±(t)superscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{(t)} finishes (in the first round, only local data ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} is used for training since the feature buffer is empty), those clients send the updated model parameters Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k} to the server, to be aggregated into a new global model parameterized by Î¸(t+1)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta^{(t+1)}. FLea uses the same aggregation strategy as FedAvg (Eq.Â (1)). Followed by that, FLea needs another step to update the global feature buffer to â„±(t+1)superscriptâ„±ğ‘¡1\mathcal{F}^{(t+1)}. A detailed training procedure can be found in AppendixÂ B and AlgorithmÂ 1. We elaborate on the main components in the procedure as follows.

Feature buffer: Letâ€™s consider the global model parameters Î¸(t)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta^{(t)} to be divided into two parts at layer lğ‘™l: Î¸(t)[:l]\theta^{(t)}[:l] and Î¸(t)[l:]\theta^{(t)}[l:]. For client kğ‘˜k, the feature vector extracted from a data point xiâˆˆğ’Ÿksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜x_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{k} is Î¸(t)[:l](xi)=fiâ„±\theta^{(t)}[:l](x_{i})=f^{\mathcal{F}}_{i}. The feature buffer from this client is the set of pairs including target labels and feature vectors (fiâ„±,yiâ„±)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â„±ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦â„±ğ‘–(f^{\mathcal{F}}_{i},y^{\mathcal{F}}_{i}). Each client randomly selects Î±ğ›¼\alpha fraction of its local data to create its feature buffer to share with others. The server gathers those local feature buffers and merge them into the global one â„±(t)superscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{(t)}. Note that a client only extracts and contributes to the global feature buffer at the round when it participates in training and the global buffer resets at every round.

Client kğ‘˜kâ€™s local training: Suppose client kğ‘˜k is selected in round tğ‘¡t, i.e., kâˆˆğ’¦(t)ğ‘˜superscriptğ’¦ğ‘¡k\in\mathcal{K}^{(t)}. As shown in FigureÂ 4, kğ‘˜k receives the global model Î¸k=Î¸(t)subscriptğœƒğ‘˜superscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{k}=\theta^{(t)} and the feature buffer â„±(t)superscriptâ„±ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{(t)}. Following the augmentation, the training loss for each batch is designed to contain two parts: one for classification (â„’câ€‹lâ€‹fsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘“\mathcal{L}_{clf}) and one for knowledge distillation form the global model (â„’dâ€‹iâ€‹ssubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ \mathcal{L}_{dis}). The classification loss â„’câ€‹lâ€‹fsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘“\mathcal{L}_{clf} is formulated as,

â„’câ€‹lâ€‹fâ€‹(â„¬,â„¬f)=1|â„¬|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆ‘câˆ’y~iâ€‹[c]â€‹logâ¡pilâ€‹[c],subscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘“â„¬superscriptâ„¬ğ‘“1â„¬subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘subscript~ğ‘¦ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{clf}(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{B}^{f})=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i}\sum_{c}-\tilde{y}_{i}[c]\log p^{l}_{i}[c], (3)

where for f~isubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–\tilde{f}_{i}, the logit is zil=Î“Î¸k,l:â€‹(f~i)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘™ğ‘–subscriptÎ“subscriptğœƒ:ğ‘˜ğ‘™absentsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–z^{l}_{i}=\Gamma_{\theta_{k,l:}}(\tilde{f}_{i}) and the probability for class cğ‘c is pilâ€‹[c]=eâ€‹xâ€‹pâ€‹(zilâ€‹[c])âˆ‘ceâ€‹xâ€‹pâ€‹(zilâ€‹[c])subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘™ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘™ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘p^{l}_{i}[c]=\frac{exp(z^{l}_{i}[c])}{\sum_{c}exp(z^{l}_{i}[c])}. The distillation lossÂ (Hinton etÂ al., 2015) is derived by the KL-divergence between the global probabilities and local probabilities as,

â„’dâ€‹iâ€‹sâ€‹(â„¬,â„¬f)=1|â„¬|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆ‘câˆ’pilâ€‹[c]â€‹logâ¡pigâ€‹[c]pilâ€‹[c],subscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ â„¬superscriptâ„¬ğ‘“1â„¬subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{dis}(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{B}^{f})=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i}\sum_{c}-p^{l}_{i}[c]\log\frac{p^{g}_{i}[c]}{p^{l}_{i}[c]}, (4)

where for f~isubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–\tilde{f}_{i} the global logit is zig=Î“Î¸l:(t)â€‹(f~i)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘”ğ‘–subscriptÎ“subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡:ğ‘™absentsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–z^{g}_{i}=\Gamma_{\theta^{(t)}_{l:}}(\tilde{f}_{i}) and the global probability is pigâ€‹[c]=eâ€‹xâ€‹pâ€‹(zigâ€‹[c])âˆ‘ceâ€‹xâ€‹pâ€‹(zigâ€‹[c])subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘”ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘”ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘p^{g}_{i}[c]=\frac{exp(z^{g}_{i}[c])}{\sum_{c}exp(z^{g}_{i}[c])}. Meanwhile, we aim to obfuscate the features to protect data privacy before they are shared out from the clients. As such, we learn the lğ‘™l layers while reducing the correlation between the features and the source data. This is achieved by minimizing the lossÂ (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2020) below,

â„’dâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹(â„¬)=Tâ€‹râ€‹(XTâ€‹Fâ€‹FTâ€‹X)Tâ€‹râ€‹(XTâ€‹X)2â€‹Tâ€‹râ€‹(FTâ€‹F)2,subscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘â„¬ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡ğ¹superscriptğ¹ğ‘‡ğ‘‹ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡ğ‘‹2ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘‡ğ¹2\mathcal{L}_{dec}(\mathcal{B})=\frac{Tr(X^{T}FF^{T}X)}{\sqrt{Tr(X^{T}X)^{2}}\sqrt{Tr(F^{T}F)^{2}}}, (5)

where Xâˆˆâ„|â„¬|Ã—dğ‘‹superscriptâ„â„¬ğ‘‘X\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{B}|\times d} and Fâˆˆâ„|â„¬|Ã—dfğ¹superscriptâ„â„¬superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘“F\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{B}|\times d^{f}} are the data and feature matrix. Note that each Xiâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘X_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and Fiâˆˆâ„dfsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptâ„superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘“F_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d^{f}} are the flattening vector for data xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} and feature fjlsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘™f_{j}^{l}. The numerator of â„’dâ€‹eâ€‹csubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{dec} measures the covariance between the data and the features, while its denominator measures the averaged pairwise distance within the data batch and feature batch, respectively. When updating the local model, the features change correspondingly. It is desired that the distance covariance decreases faster than the feature inner distance for each batch. Since when reducing the correlation, we hope the features can maintain classification ability, and thus we optimize all the loss functions jointly, as follows,

â„’=â„’câ€‹lâ€‹fâ€‹(â„¬,â„¬f)+Î»1â€‹â„’dâ€‹iâ€‹sâ€‹(â„¬,â„¬f)+Î»2â€‹â„’dâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹(â„¬),â„’subscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘“â„¬superscriptâ„¬ğ‘“subscriptğœ†1subscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ â„¬superscriptâ„¬ğ‘“subscriptğœ†2subscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘â„¬\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{L}_{clf}(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{B}^{f})+\lambda_{1}\mathcal{L}_{dis}(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{B}^{f})+\lambda_{2}\mathcal{L}_{dec}(\mathcal{B}), (6)

where Î»1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1} and Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} are the weights to trade-off classification and privacy preserving. The local update is then achieved by Î¸kâ†Î¸kâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚Î¸kâ†subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğœƒğ‘˜ğœ‚â„’subscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k}\leftarrow\theta_{k}-\eta\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\theta_{k}}, where Î·ğœ‚\eta controls the learning rate.

Feature buffer updating: After the global model aggregation and broadcasting, client kğ‘˜k extracts the features from the new model parameterized by Î¸(t+1)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta^{(t+1)} from layer lğ‘™l to formulate the feature set. Those sets will be sent to the server to replace the old ones, updating the feature buffer to â„±â€‹(t+1)â„±ğ‘¡1\mathcal{F}{(t+1)}. The iterations continue until the global model converges.

5 Evaluation

5.1 Experimental setup

Datsets. We evaluate FLea on two different data modalities, classifying images (CIFAR101010Â Krizhevsky etÂ al. (2009)) and audio (UrbanSound888KÂ Salamon etÂ al. (2014)). Both datasets have 101010 classes. Following strategies fromÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022a), we distribute the training data to |K|ğ¾|K| clients via quantity-based skew (Quantity(qğ‘q)) and distribution-based skew (Dirichlet(Î¼ğœ‡\mu)) splits. More details can be found in the AppendixÂ C.1.

Model architectures and hyper-parameters. We classify images in CIFAR101010 using MobileNet_V2Â (Sandler etÂ al., 2018) that has 181818 blocks consisting of multiple convolutional and pooling layers. FLea shares the features after the first block as illustrated in TableÂ 4. For audio classification, the samples are first transformed into spectrograms and fed into a 4 layer CNN model, which we termed as AudioNet. We share the feature from the second convolutional layer and the details of architecture can be found in TableÂ 5.

We use the Adam optimizer for local training with an initial learning rate of 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} and decay it by 2%percent22\% per communication round until 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5}. The size of the local batch is 646464, and we run 101010 local epochs for 100100100 clients setting for CIFAR10 and 151515 local epochs for other settings. 10%percent1010\% of clients are randomly sampled at each round. We run 100100100 communications and take the best accuracy as the final result. Without particular mention, we use Î»âˆ¼Bâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹(2,2)similar-toğœ†ğµğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘22\lambda\sim Beta(2,2) for Eq.Â (2), and Î»1=1,Î»2=3formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ†11subscriptğœ†23\lambda_{1}=1,\lambda_{2}=3 for the loss in Eq.Â (6). For all results, we report the mean and standard deviation of the accuracy from five runs with different random seeds. More details are presented in AppendixÂ C.2.

Baselines. We compareÂ FLea againstÂ FedAvg, and then loss-based methods: i)i)Â FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b), ii)ii)Â FedDecorrÂ (Shi etÂ al., 2022), iii)iii)Â FedLCÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022a), and iv)iv)Â FedNTDÂ (Lee etÂ al., 2022), as well as data augmentation-based methods: i)i)Â FedBRÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023), ii)ii)Â CCVRÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2021), iii)iii)Â FedGenÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2022), iv)iv)Â FedDataÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018) and v)v)Â FedMixÂ (Yoon etÂ al., 2020). All baselines are hyper-parameter optimized to report their best performances. The specific setting can be found in AppendixÂ C.3.

5.2 Results

Overall accuracy. We summarize the overall comparison to baselines in TableÂ 2, and present extended results in AppendixÂ C.4. FLea consistently outperforms the baselines and closes the gap to FedData across different data scarcity and label skew levels for the two tasks.

Among the compared baselines that only share model parameters, FedNTD achieves the best performance in most cases, but it is outperformed by FLea by 7.03âˆ¼17.62%similar-to7.03percent17.627.03\sim 17.62\% across all the settings. Notably, the most significant improvement occurs when the label skew intensifies, specifically with the Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹hâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(0.1)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘â„ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘¡0.1Dirichlet(0.1) distribution. This suggests that FLea, by utilizing features from other clients to compensate for locally absent distributions, is more effective in mitigating local bias.Furthermore, we observe that FLea exhibits faster learning compared to the non-augmentation methods. Illustrated in FigureÂ 6, FLea consistently requires fewer communication rounds to attain a target model accuracy. Although this does not necessarily imply superior communication efficiency for FLea, as additional features need to be transferred and stored. FLea still proves advantageous in scenarios where extensive communication with a large number of clients is not always feasible.

Compared to the augmentation-based counterparts, FLea is also superior. FedMix is the state-of-the-art data augmentation-based approach, yet FLea surpasses FedMix with a performance gain ranging from 2.59%percent2.592.59\% to 6.27%percent6.276.27\%. Besides, we present the results for sharing different fractions of the features in FigureÂ 6. It is evident that a fraction of 10%percent1010\% can significantly boost the performance while when sharing more, the advantage over FedMix still keeps. All those demonstrate the superiority of employing feature augmentation across all classes to enhance local model generalization. In Sec.Â 5.3, we will further show that FLea is also more privacy-persevering than FedMix.

Impact of hyper-parameters. We illustrate how we identify the hyper-parameters Î»1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1} and Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} for the loss function and ağ‘a in the Bâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹ağµğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘Beta distribution for the augmentation in FigureÂ 7. We first set Î»2=0subscriptğœ†20\lambda_{2}=0 (without obfuscating the features) and search the value for Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2}. As shown in FigureÂ 7(a), we found that Î»1>1subscriptğœ†11\lambda_{1}>1 can improve the performance compared to that without the distilling loss (Î»1=0subscriptğœ†10\lambda_{1}=0), but if the weight is too large (Î»1>4subscriptğœ†14\lambda_{1}>4) it harms the performance. The pattern is similar with other Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2}, and thus we informally use Î»1=1subscriptğœ†11\lambda_{1}=1 for all experiments. With Î»1=1subscriptğœ†11\lambda_{1}=1, we further study how Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} impacts the trade-off between privacy preservation (reflected by the reduced correlation) and the feature utility (reflected by the model accuracy), as shown in FigureÂ 7(b). Enlarging Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} can significantly enhance privacy protection (referring to the increasing 1âˆ’cÂ¯1Â¯ğ‘1-\bar{c}) but decreases the final performance. We finally use Î»2=3subscriptğœ†23\lambda_{2}=3 when the cÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{c} reduces to about 0.720.720.72 while maintaining a strong accuracy of about 57%percent5757\%. We also suggest future applications using 2âˆ¼6similar-to262\sim 6 for the trade-off. In FigureÂ 7(c), we demonstrate that the final performance is not sensitive to the parameter of the Bâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹ağµğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘Beta distribution since we always have an expectation of 0.50.50.5 for Î»ğœ†\lambda.

5.3 FLea mitigates privacy risk

FLea aims to mitigate the privacy leakage from three aspects: i) reducing feature exposure by only sharing features with a fraction of clients, ii) defending from data reconstruction attack, and iii) preventing the sensitive context information from being identified. We demonstrate FLea is more privacy-preserving than FedMix and FedData as follows.

Feature exposure. To quantify the feature exposure, we define a feature exchange matrix Î¾âˆˆâ„|K|Ã—|K|ğœ‰superscriptâ„ğ¾ğ¾\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{|K|\times|K|}. Î¾i,j(t)=1superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡1\xi_{i,j}^{(t)}=1 denotes client iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j have exchanged features (from Î±ğ›¼\alpha fraction of local data) for at least once until (including) tğ‘¡t-th round, otherwise Î¾i,j(t)=0superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡0\xi_{i,j}^{(t)}=0. The the feature exposure is measured by Ïµ(t)=âˆ‘i,jÎ¾i,j(t)/K2superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡superscriptğ¾2\epsilon^{(t)}=\sum_{i,j}\xi_{i,j}^{(t)}/K^{2} ( 0â‰¤Ïµ(t)â‰¤10superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡10\leq\epsilon^{(t)}\leq 1), and a smaller Ïµ(t)superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon^{(t)} is better. As FedData and FedMix gather data or data averages and broadcast the data to all clients before local model training, Ïµ(t)=100%superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡percent100\epsilon^{(t)}=100\% consistently. We illustrate Ïµ(t)superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon^{(t)} for FLea in FigureÂ 8. From the figure it can be observed that the exposure of FLea grows slowly. In our experiments, the model converges within 505050 rounds, by when Ïµ(t)â‰¤40%superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡percent40\epsilon^{(t)}\leq 40\%.

It is worth noting that feature exposure is not equivalent to privacy leakage, as the features of FLea do not leak source data. As shown in FigureÂ 7(b), our loss function with â„’dâ€‹eâ€‹csubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{dec} can effectively reduce the correlation between features and raw data, so that the privacy is not compromised. To demonstrate that FLea can defend from data reconstruction and context identification attacks, we construct testbeds by assuming the attacker can access the entire CIFAR10 training set. The setup and results are summarized in AppendixÂ C Sec.Â D, and the main findings are given blew.

Data reconstruction. Assume one client is selected to share the feature of an image, e.g., the dog image in FigureÂ (a), in a certain communication round (when c=0.4ğ‘0.4c=0.4), an optimal attacker tries to reconstruct the image from the feature and it will end up to the image as shown in FigureÂ (c*). The original attribute, i.e., the color distribution cannot be recovered and thus privacy is preserved.

Identifying context information. As we mentioned before, one advantage of FLea over FedMix is that FLea can better protect the context information. Again using the example, if one client is selected to share some augmentations from the data including the dog image in FigureÂ (a*), the context attacker can easily detect the context marker in FigureÂ (b*) shared by FedMix, but can be difficult to detect that from the feature in FigureÂ (c) shared by FLea. Therefore, the context privacy is better preserved.

6 Conclusions

We proposed FLea, a novel approach to tackle scarce and label-skewed data in FL. Feature augmentation is employed to mitigate over-fitting and local bias simultaneously. Extensive experiments demonstrate that FLea remarkably outperforms the state-of-the-art baselines.

Limitations. In reality, because of extra feature sharing, FLea can introduce some extra overheads like communication and storage. We leave the improvement of the efficiency for real-world applications for future work. To enhance privacy, FLea can be trivially combined with methods protecting model parameters (such as DP-SGDÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016)), however, improving the statistical privacy risks posed by feature sharing is hard due to the challenges originating from the stochasticity in modeling, data distribution in the clients, the high dimensionality of real-valued features, etc. We thus leave this as a future work. We anticipate that our work will inspire further investigations to comprehensively study feature sharing in the low data regime.

Appendix A Experimental setup for Section 3

Federated Learning Setup. In Sec.Â 3Â Limitations of Previous Work and Insights, we employ CIFAR10 for an empirical comparison. We conduct six groups of experiments to simulate different levels of label skew and scarcity, as introduced below.

  • â€¢

    (a) The training set of CIFAR10 is uniformly distributed to 101010 clients, resulting in each local dataset having a size of 500050005000 (|ğ’Ÿk|=5000subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜5000|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=5000) and 101010 classes (IID). More specifically, each local dataset has 500500500 samples per class.

  • â€¢

    (b) CIFAR10 is uniformly distributed to 100100100 clients. Thus each local dataset has a size of 500500500 (|ğ’Ÿk|=500subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜500|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=500), 101010 classes (IID) with each class containing 505050 samples.

  • â€¢

    (c) CIFAR10 is uniformly distributed to 500500500 clients. Each local dataset have a size of 100100100 (|ğ’Ÿk|=100subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜100|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=100), 101010 classes (IID) with each class containing 101010 samples.

  • â€¢

    (d) The training set of CIFAR10 is distributed to 101010 clients, but only three out of ten classes are distributed to each client (non-IID), resulting in each local dataset having a size of 500050005000 (|ğ’Ÿk|=5000subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜5000|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=5000) and approximately 166616661666 samples for each class.

  • â€¢

    (e) Similar to (d), CIFAR10 is distributed to 100100100 clients (|ğ’Ÿk|=500subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜500|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=500) with each client containing 333 classes (non-IID). This data distribution is shown in FigureÂ 9(a).

  • â€¢

    (f) Similar to (d), CIFAR10 is distributed to 500500500 clients (|ğ’Ÿk|=100subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜100|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=100). Each client contains 333 classes (non-IID) with about 333333 samples per class.

For CIFAR10 classification, we employ MobileNet_V2, which has 181818 blocks consisting of multiple convolutional and pooling layersÂ (Sandler etÂ al., 2018). We use the Adam optimizer for local training with an initial learning rate of 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} and decay it by 2%percent22\% per communication round until 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5}. For (a) and (d), all clients will participate in the training in each round, while for the other groups, we will randomly select 10%percent1010\% of the clients for each round. The size of the local batch is 646464, and we run 101010 local epochs for groups (a, b, d, e) and 555 local epochs for groups (c, f). We run 100 communication rounds for all groups to ensure global convergence.

Experimental setup for Figure 1: To compare the performance of existing methods with , we use CIFAR101010 dataset and report the classification accuracy of the global model based on the global testing set. We compare FedAvg with loss-based methods such as FedDecorr and FedNTD, as well as data augmentation-based methods like FedMix and FedData. They are the most representative methods in each category. FedMix is implemented by averaging every 101010 samples and sharing the result globally. The shared averaged data is then combined with local data according to a Beta distribution (with the a=2ğ‘2a=2) for local training. In the case of FedData, we collect 10%percent1010\% of the data (randomly chosen) from each client and share it globally, in the first communication round. To simulate varying scarcity levels, we split the CIFAR101010 training set (comprising 50,0005000050,000 samples in total) into 500050005000, 500500500, and 100100100 training samples on average per client, which ends up with 101010, 100100100 and 500500500 clients finally. Other settings are the same with the main experiments as introduced in Sec.Â 5.1.

Experimental setup for Figure 2: DB scoreÂ (Davies & Bouldin, 1979) is defined as the average similarity measuring each cluster with its most similar cluster, where similarity is the ratio of within-cluster distances to between-cluster distances. Thus, clusters which are farther apart and less dispersed will result in a better score. The minimum score is zero, with lower values indicating better clustering. To calculate the score for features, we use the ground-true class labels as cluster labels, and use Euclidean distance between features to measure the similarity.

For a fair comparison, the local training for all clients starts from a same global status with an accuracy of 40%percent4040\%. The features of the testing set from the initial global model present a DB of 4.84.84.8. We run one communication round and report the performance for the global model. In this round, for |ğ’Ÿk|=5000subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜5000|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=5000 we aggregate 101010 clients while for |ğ’Ÿk|=100subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜100|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=100 we aggregate 505050 clients, so that the total samples used for model training are kept unchanged. For |ğ’Ÿk|=100+1000subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜1001000|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=100+1000 group, we additionally give the selected 505050 clients 100010001000 samples (gathered in the first round) to aid local training. In FigureÂ 2, for local models, we report the averaged DB across clients.

Appendix C Details of Experiments

Audio data: We also test FLea using UrbanSound888K datasetÂ Salamon etÂ al. (2014). This dataset contains 873287328732 labeled sound excerpts (â‰¤4â€‹sabsent4ğ‘ \leq 4s) of urban sounds from 10 classes: air conditioner, car horn, children playing, dog bark, drilling, engine idling, gun shot, jackhammer, siren, and street music. For experiments, we randomly hold out 20%percent2020\% (about 170017001700 samples) for testing and distribute the rest (about 700070007000 samples) to Kğ¾K clients for training. We report the results for K=70ğ¾70K=70 and K=140ğ¾140K=140, using the Qâ€‹uâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹yâ€‹(3)ğ‘„ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦3Quantity(3), Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹hâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(0.5)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘â„ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘¡0.5Dirichlet(0.5), and Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹hâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(0.1)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘â„ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘¡0.1Dirichlet(0.1) splits.

To better illustrate the data scarcity problem, we visualize the distribution for the local data size in FigureÂ 10. As it shown, when we distribute the training set of CIAFR10 (50,0005000050,000 samples) to 101010 clients using a Dirichlet distribution parameterized by 0.1, these clients will present different class distributions, and the total number of local samples ranges from 285328532853 to 819981998199. This is the commonly explored non-IID setting. In this paper, we further explore scarce non-IID data, and thus we split the data into 100100100 and 500500500 clients. As a result, the number of samples per client reduces significantly: the median number drops from 568556855685 to 909090 when the number of clients increases from 101010 to 500500500, as shown in FigureÂ 10(a). This is the realistic scenario that we are interested in. It is also worth mentioning that data scarcity is independent of label skew and it can happen in the IID scenario. As shown in FigureÂ 10(b), the local data covers 101010 classes uniformly, but the data scarcity problem becomes severe when the number of client increase.

We use the Adam optimizer for local training with an initial learning rate of 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} and decay it by 2%percent22\% per communication round until 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5}. The size of the local batch is 646464, and we run 101010 local epochs for 100100100 clients setting and 151515 local epochs for the rest. For feature augmentation, we use Bâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹(2,2)ğµğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘22Beta(2,2). We run 100100100 communications and take the best accuracy as the final result. For all results, we report the mean and standard deviation of the accuracy from five runs with different random seeds.

C.3 Baseline Implementation

More details for baseline implementations are summarized as blew,

  • â€¢

    FedProx: We adapt the implementation fromÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b). We test the weight for local model regularization in [0.1,0.01,0.001]0.10.010.001[0.1,0.01,0.001] and report the best results.

  • â€¢

    FedLC: it calibrates the logits before softmax cross-entropy according to the probability of occurrence of each classÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022a). We test the scaling factor in the calibration from 0.1 to 1 and report the best performance.

  • â€¢

    FedDecorr: This method applies a regularization term during local training that encourages different dimensions of the low-dimensional features to be uncorrelatedÂ (Shi etÂ al., 2022). We adapt the official implementation222https://github.com/bytedance/FedDecorr and suggested hyper-parameter in the source paper. We found that this method can only outperform FedAvg with fewer than 101010 client for CIFAR101010.

  • â€¢

    FedNTD: It prevents the local model drift by distilling knowledge from the global modelÂ (Lee etÂ al., 2022). We use the default distilling weights from the original paper as the setting are similar333https://github.com/Lee-Gihun/FedNTD.git.

  • â€¢

    FedBRÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023): this approach leverage 323232 mini-batch data averages without class labels as data augmentation. A min-max algorithm is designed, where the max step aims to make local features for all classes more distinguishable while the min step enforces the local classifier to predict uniform probabilities for the global data averages. We adapt the official implementation444https://github.com/lins-lab/fedbr in our framework.

  • â€¢

    CCVR: It collects a global feature set before the final fully connected linear of the converged global model, i.e., the model trained via FedAvg, to calibrate the classifier on the serverÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2021). For a fair comparison, we use the same amount of features as our method for this baseline, and we fit the model using the features instead of distributions as used inÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2021). This allows us to report the optimal performance of CCVR.

  • â€¢

    FedGen: It is a method that trains a data generator using the global model as the discriminator to create synthetic data for local trainingÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2022). The generator outputs x^isubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–\hat{x}_{i} with input (yi,zi)subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–(y_{i},z_{i}) where zisubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–z_{i} is a sample for Normal distribution. The generator is a convolutional neural network consisting of four ConvTranspose2d layers to upsample feature maps. We train the first 30 rounds by normal FedAvg and after 30 rounds, we use the global model as the discriminator to distinguish with the generated data x^isubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–\hat{x}_{i} is real or not.

  • â€¢

    FedData: In this baseline, we assume the server waits until all the clients have shared 10%percent1010\% of their local data in the beginning round. The gathered data will be sent to clients to mix with local data for model training.

  • â€¢

    FedMix: Similar with FedData, we assume the server waits until all the clients have shared their data averages.we use a mini-batch of 101010 to aggregate the samples. Different from FedBR The gathered data will be sent to clients, combing with local data based on the Beta distribution.

C.4 Extended results

TablesÂ 6 andÂ 7 for additional results corresponding to different local data sizes, supplementing the information presented in TableÂ 2.

Results for CIFAR10 classification. The analysis for TableÂ 6 is elaborated on as follows. Among loss-based approaches, FedNTD is the best, showing a strong ability to handle data scarcity and label skew (about 10%percent1010\% improvement from FedAvg), while other loss-based FL methods present marginal gain from FedAvg. The outstanding performance of FedNTD are mainly attributed to its knowledge distillation component, mitigating the local over-fitting as well as model bias. FLea further improves FedNTD by 3âˆ¼5%similar-to3percent53\sim 5\% when the average local data size is 500500500, and the superiority of FLea is more remarkable with increasing level of data scarcity, e.g., when the average local data size reduces to 100100100, the performance gain reaches 17.6%percent17.617.6\% (Dirichlet(0.1) group).

For data augmentation-based baselines, FedMix performs the best and for most of the cases, it is the SOTA baseline excluding FedData. When sharing the same proportion of global proxies (FedMix shares data averages while FLea shares features), FLea outperforms FedMix by 2âˆ¼6%similar-to2percent62\sim 6\% across all experiments. We report the performance of FedData as an Oracle. It is plausible that FLea cannot beat FedData given FedData shares raw data with privacy protection.

FLea also presents more stable performance compared to FedNTD and FedMix. As shown in FigureÂ 11, FLea converges after 404040 communication rounds, with notably higher averaged accuracy and smaller variance compared to the other two best baselines. We also demonstrate each component in FLea yields independent contribution to the overall performance in AppendixÂ C Sec.Â C.5.

Results for UrbanSound8K classification. Similarly to the performance for audio classification, FLea consistently achieve the best accuracy across different settings. Given that the total size of UrbanSound8K is smaller than CIFAR10, this audio classification has more sever data scarcity problem globally and locally. This explains why FedMix is the best baseline uniformly for this task. Nevertheless, FLea outperforms FedMix by 2.59%âˆ¼7.80%similar-topercent2.59percent7.802.59\%\sim 7.80\%.

C.5 Ablation study for FLea

As introduced in Sec.Â 4, our FLea leverages feature augmentation by combing local and global features according to the weights following a Beta distribution. Now we give the results to demonstrate the advantage of introducing randomness to improve the model generalization: we use fixed Î»ğœ†\lambda instead of sampling it from Bâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹(2,2)ğµğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘22Beta(2,2) (refer to FLeaÂ (l=5ğ‘™5l=5, Î»=0.5ğœ†0.5\lambda=0.5) group in TableÂ 8). We also give the results when removing â„’dâ€‹iâ€‹ssubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ \mathcal{L}_{dis} from the training loss (refer to FLeaÂ (l=5ğ‘™5l=5, Î»1=0subscriptğœ†10\lambda_{1}=0) group in TableÂ 8). It is evident that our complete version of FLea always performs the best.

We also discuss the impact of layer lğ‘™l, from which layer the features are extracted. It is a trade-off between between privacy protection and the utilization of features. A smaller lğ‘™l indicates the features are closer to the raw data while the privacy vulnerability increases. In Sec.Â 5.3, we have demonstrated that l=5ğ‘™5l=5 with the de-correlation loss can well defend against privacy attacks in our simulations. In TableÂ 8, we also show that sharing features from l=1ğ‘™1l=1 can enhance FLea while from l=9ğ‘™9l=9 can lead to a slight performance decline. For real-world applications (beyond CIFAR101010), we choose lğ‘™l according to the specific performance and privacy requirements. It is also worth mentioning that, as FLea is designed to leverage the latest feature buffer, lğ‘™l wonâ€™t necessarily to be fixed. On the contrary, lğ‘™l can be dynamically altered during training based on the performance and privacy requirements.

C.6 Reflections for baselines

More results for CCVR. We evaluated the baseline CCVR by using features from different layers to calibrate the global model, and the performance is reported in TableÂ 9. Those results clearly suggest that leveraging features from shallower layers does not lead to further performance improvements. This suggests that post-hoc calibration has limited capability in mitigating the local drift, which is the fundamental cause of degradation in FL on non-IID data. Our Flea shows an evidently stronger performance.

More reflection for FedNTD. From both FigureÂ 1 and TableÂ 6, we can see FedNTD is a strong baseline for both data scarcity and label skew. FedNTD was devised to address the non-IID setting, but we find it is also able to alleviate issues with data scarcity in the IID setting. This suggests global knowledge distilling can mitigate local over-fitting. However, as the data becomes scarce, the distillation ability declines, herein the performance gain drops. Instead of using local data for knowledge distilling, in FLea, we leverage the augmented features to distill the knowledge from the global model into the local model.

Appendix D Privacy study

Now we present the experimental setup for privacy attacks. We use the Quantity(333) data splits when |K|=100ğ¾100|K|=100 as an example for studying, as in other settings either the label is more skewed or the local data is more scarce, privacy attack can hardly be more effective than this setting. This is to present the attack defending for the most vulnerable case. As the correlation between the features and the data is continuously reduced (shown in FigureÂ 12), we report the reconstruction and context detection performance for c=0.65ğ‘0.65c=0.65 (the 1sâ€‹tsuperscript1ğ‘ ğ‘¡1^{st} round) and c=0.40ğ‘0.40c=0.40 (the 10tâ€‹hsuperscript10ğ‘¡â„10^{th} round) for reference.

Data reconstruction. We first implemented a data reconstruction attacker, following the approach described inÂ Dosovitskiy & Brox (2016), the attacker constructed a decoder for the purpose of reconstruction. Specifically, the attacker targeted the converged global model trained using the Quantity(333) distribution, ensuring a fair comparison. The decoder architecture, designed to match the MobileNet_V2 architecture, comprised four conv2d layers (refer to TableÂ 10) to reconstruct the original data from the provided features. For visualization purposes, the CIFAR101010 images were cropped to a size of 32Ã—32323232\times 32 pixels without any normalization. The decoder took the features extracted from the global model as input and generated a reconstructed image, which served as the basis for calculating the mean squared error (MSE).

To train the decoder, we utilized the entire CIFAR101010 training set, conducting training for 202020 epochs and employing a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001. This approach allowed us to evaluate the fidelity of the reconstructed data and compare it with the original input, providing insights into the effectiveness of our proposed feature interpolation method. We use the testing set and the target global model (c=0.65ğ‘0.65c=0.65 and c=0.40ğ‘0.40c=0.40 ) to extract features for reconstruction. FigureÂ 13(b)(a) shows the training MSE while the exampled images are from the testing set. For c=0.65ğ‘0.65c=0.65, i.e., after the first round, in FigureÂ 12, the sensitive attributes are removed (e.g., the color of the dog). After 101010 rounds when c<0.4ğ‘0.4c<0.4, information is further compressed and the privacy protection is enhanced. Overall, with â„’dâ€‹eâ€‹csubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{dec}, the correlation between data and features is reduced, preventing the image from being reconstructed.

Identifying context information. In this attack, we assume that the attacker explicitly knows the context information and thus can generate large amounts of negative (clear data) and positive (clear data with context marker) pairs to train a context classifier (which is very challenging and unrealistic but this is for the sake of testing). Real-world attack will be far more challenging than our simulations.

The context identification attacker is interested in finding out if a given feature fğ‘“f, is from the source data with a specific context or not. We simulate the context information by adding a color square to the image (to mimic camera broken), as illustrated in FigureÂ 8. We use a binary classifier consisting of four linear layers to classify the flattened features or images. To train the classifier, we add the context marker to half of the training set. To report the identification performance, we add the same marker to half of the testing set. In FigureÂ 13(b)(b), the identification accuracy for FedMix and our FLea are given. We measure the attacking difficulty by how many training sample the model need to achieve a certain accuracy. The results in FigureÂ 13(b)(b) suggest that FLea needs times of training sample than FedMix for different correlations. This demonstrates that FLea can better protect the context privacy.

All the above results lead to the conclusion that by reducing feature exposure and mitigating the correlation between the features and source data, FLea safely protect the privacy associated with feature sharing while achieving favorable performance gain in addressing the label skew and data scarcity simultaneously.
